text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] be a [mathjaxinline]6\times 4[/mathjaxinline] matrix. The equation [mathjaxinline]Ax = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline] has the solution [mathjaxinline]x = \mathbf{0}[/mathjaxinline], which we call the trivial solution. If there are no solutions other than the trivial solutions, how many pivots must [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] have when row-reduced?

font.p: The vector [mathjaxinline]x[/mathjaxinline] lives in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^4[/mathjaxinline], so there are four variables in this equation. If the trivial solution is the unique solution, then we cannot have free variables when the augmented matrix [mathjaxinline]\left[ \begin{array}{c:c} A & \mathbf{0}\end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] is row-reduced. That means [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] will have a pivot in each of its four columns.
